sub_topic: Calculation of the corrosion current density of a metal in a given environment
message_1: What is the corrosion current density of an iron metal in a 0.5 M hydrochloric acid solution when the measured electrochemical cell current is 2.5 mA and the surface area of the iron electrode is 5 cm²? All other experimental conditions remain constant.
message_2:
The corrosion current density (i_corr) can be calculated using the formula:

i_corr = I_corr / A

where I_corr is the corrosion current (in mA) and A is the surface area of the electrode (in cm²).

Given the electrochemical cell current (I_corr) is 2.5 mA and the surface area of the iron electrode (A) is 5 cm², we can calculate the corrosion current density as follows:

i_corr = 2.5 mA / 5 cm² = 0.5 mA/cm²

So, the corrosion current density of the iron metal in a 0.5 M hydrochloric acid solution is 0.5 mA/cm².
